For those that don't know, Youtube Red is a subscription service
available here on youtube
To find it, you go to Youtube.com/red.
If you sign up, you get a month free trial
And then after that it's $9.99 a month.
You don't get ads on Youtube,
you can have background play if you just want to listen to the audio
and if you want to download a video you can.
and then you can watch it offline.
And the side benefit, although it's more for creators out there
is that even though there's not an ad played on a video
they actually get paid.
So how do creators get paid with YouTube Red?
Well its based on who you, a YouTube Red user, watch[es]
And the big thing here is that it's based on minutes.
So it doesn't matter about the number of videos a person watches, it just matters how long they are watching you.
So for example: let's say you watch my channel and another channel where they put up like an hour long video podcast.
My videos on average these days are 12 minutes so you watch five of those.
Boom, 60 minutes.
Once a week, this podcast channel, they upload a one hour long video:
Boom, 60 minutes.
Even though they only uploaded one video and I uploaded five,
we are watch time equals.
Which means if you only watched our channels, we are splitting the money that comes from your YouTube Red subscription, equally.
And in this scenario, you are watching the videos from beginning to end completely.
You're not stopping in between.
Cause it doesn't matter how long the videos is, it matters how long you watched it.
So unlike regular ads which really promote:
"put out as much content as possible. It can be short, it doesn't matter."
The creators that will benefit the most are creators who make long form content on YouTube.
At least as far as YouTube Red's concerned.
Also another fantastic new way tha-that YouTubers can make money on YouTube is Super Chat.
I talked about Super Chat when YouTube first launched it.
But now you actually have creators like PewDiePie, Felix, using it during live streams and making a ton of money.
Instead of your normal live stream donations, what you have is
someone typing out a comment saying:

Well I--I think you mean unthrottled. Bandwidth throttling is the intentional slow down of internet services.
And in my opinion and currently the FCC's opinion, the internet is a utility.
There's already a system in place for throttling speed. Tha-that you have tiers of internet service.
When you're buying your internet, you're deciding how much of the internet...hoes...that are gonna turn on in your house or in your business.
Different speed, different price, when it comes to phones sure there are "unlimited" plans,
But most, if not all at this point, throttle after a certain amount of usage
Others have capped usage.
And because the cost there is on the user, it incentifies as the businesses, the sites out, that are like a Netflix.
They wanna be usable and accessible to the masses. They have to figure out how to get their information to be as tiny as possible to get to you.
But once you change it to where a user maybe has 30MB down(load), 30MB up(load)
But all of a sudden the ISP gets to say "you know what even though you have that internet service, because you're using Netflix who's not gonna pay us
their data is just gonna trickle to you unless you wanna go to our new service which we own or we're friends with
they have the full speed fast lane."
